Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Copolymer Monomer Sequence Determination Using Interaction Chromatography

POR.DRECONTENT:
Part of our research in the Genzer group focuses on the determination of sequence distributions in copolymers. A polymer is a large molecule composed of smaller molecules chemically bonded together. In a copolymer, these smaller molecules, called monomers, have two possible identities. The relative amounts and locations (sequence distribution) of these two monomers play a significant role in the physical behavior of the copolymer. Adjusting the amount of each monomer in the copolymer is relatively straightforward, but controlling and determining the sequence distribution is not. Developing methods that provide researchers that level of control will enable the fine tuning of physical properties for a variety of applications.

In collaboration with Prof. Taihyun Chang at POSTECH in Pohang, South Korea, we attempted to use a characterization technique called high-performance liquid chromatography to analyze copolymer sequence distributions. The Chang group are recognized experts in this technique, which involves moving a dissolved polymer sample through a column containing very small beads as packing. The polymer molecules interact with these beads in different ways depending on the size, composition, and--based on our hypothesis--sequence distribution. By holding the first two parameters constant, we aimed to isolate differences in copolymer sequence distribution. 

Our collaboration that summer in South Korea focused on determining ideal conditions for separating the copolymer samples synthesized in the United States. We developed methods that analyzed the copolymers based on size, and began experimenting with combinations of different solvents for analysis based on composition. This collaboration continues across the sea, and the practical knowledge gained during the site visit has already proven useful for the Genzer group.
